content.value_statement: This skill helps developers create Model Context Protocol servers with tools, resources, prompts, and interactive widgets using the mcp-use framework. Note: This skill is deprecated; use mcp-app-builder instead.
actual_capabilities: Create MCP servers with tools, resources, and prompts using mcp-use framework
Define interactive React-based widgets for visual output
Use response helpers (text, object, markdown, html, image) for formatting
Bootstrap new MCP projects with proper structure
Design server architecture (tools vs widgets vs resources)

best_practices: Always add .describe() to Zod schema fields for clear parameter documentation
Use widgets when visual or interactive output improves user experience
Reference design-and-architecture.md before jumping to code implementation
anti_patterns: Jumping to code without reading design-and-architecture.md first
Using tools for everything when widgets would provide better UX
Skipping .describe() on schema fields, making parameters unclear

faq.question: Is this skill still supported?
faq.answer: No, this skill is deprecated. Use mcp-app-builder instead for new MCP server development.

faq.question: What is the difference between tools and widgets?
faq.answer: Tools perform backend actions and return data. Widgets are React components that provide visual or interactive output. Use tools for data operations and widgets when visual representation improves UX.

faq.question: How do I handle errors in MCP tools?
faq.answer: Use the error() response helper to return error messages. Check for missing required data and return errors before processing.

faq.question: Can I use environment variables in my MCP server?
faq.answer: Yes, access configuration via process.env in your tool/resource callbacks. Create .env.example to document required variables.

faq.question: What response helpers are available?
faq.answer: text(), object(), markdown(), html(), image(), audio(), binary(), error(), mix(), and widget() for different output formats.

faq.question: How do I test my MCP server?
faq.answer: Run your server locally with server.listen() and test tools/resources using a Claude or Codex client connected to your server.
